Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Promoting a Growth Mindset Using Automated Feedback

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The "Promoting a Growth Mindset Using Automated Feedback" project will develop and evaluate a new strategy for generating automated feedback on programming assignments that will provide a more welcoming experience for students, recognizing the effort they put in as they work on solutions. The goal of the project will be to promote the adoption of a "growth mindset" - a belief that one's abilities will improve with practice and hard work, which is associated with a range of improved educational outcomes. This strategy will encompass four key ideas: a measurement approach for assessing student effort; the use of non-points-based bonuses to reward effort and recognize hard work for positive reinforcement; heat maps of student code to highlight where bugs are located; and a strategy for clearly identifying the top priority for students to tackle in order to make progress.

During the first year of the project, all three schools will collect baseline data using existing "conventional" feedback approaches. The new feedback intervention will be evaluated in years two and three of the project. Quantitative and qualitative data will be collected and analyzed to examine changes in performance and students' behavior. A mixed-method data collection plan will triangulate the quantitative and qualitative data with the review of literature and the researchers' direct experience in teaching these courses to reach conclusions regarding research questions of the study and provide the framework for the design of a scalable and replicable intervention to improve students' performance in the programming projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Work on the grant Collaborative Research: Promoting a Growth Mindset Using Automated Feedback spanned three institutions working in collaboration. Dr. Jadud’s contribution to the work was to 1) involve undergraduates in the research process, and 2) engage in data collection in a context that could be compared-and-contrasted with the larger institutions taking part in the work.

At the end of the first year of the grant, Dr. Jadud moved from Berea College to Bates College, interrupting the involvement of Berea students in the work. At Bates, Dr. Jadud was charged with launching a new curriculum in computing, meaning there was not a ready pipeline of students to engage in computational research. At the end of the first year, Fintan Browne, a rising sophomore, engaged in data visualization work and began laying the foundations for a machine learning analysis of the rich data being generated at Virigina Tech by Dr. Stephen Edwards and his students.

During the spring and summer of 2019, two more students (Leo Crossman and Sam Hoffman) carried this work forward. Leo’s work was poised to serve as a foundation for his senior thesis and possible subsequent publication. Dr. Jadud left Bates at the end of the summer of 2019 for industry. Due to the complexities of dealing with Covid-19, the courtesy appointment at Carleton College was discontinued before students could be recruited to advance the state of the research.

The early-stage findings have informed the work at the other institutions in the research partnership, and the team remains hopeful that Leo’s work will see publication. No publications have come from this work to date.
